race.name: Ouray Gravel Grinder
race.tagline: Where gravel meets the sky - high-altitude suffering in Colorado's Switzerland

distances.name: Alpine Loop
distances.description: High elevation loop topping 12,000+ ft via Engineer and Cinnamon Passes

distances.name: Black Bear Pass
distances.description: Classic San Juan jeep road - most dangerous 4x4 road in Colorado

terrain.description: Extreme high-altitude San Juan Mountain passes on jeep roads, topping above 12,000 ft

typical.conditions: High altitude mountain weather, 72-81 thunderstorm days/year, monsoon season July-August, hypothermia risk

uniqueCharacteristics: Alpine Loop and Black Bear Pass routes

logistics.explanation: Remote location with Montrose airport 35 miles away and limited small-town services. Research reveals no specific 'Ouray Gravel Grinder' event exists - the area offers exceptional self-supported riding but requires 5+ days for altitude acclimation at 7,792 ft base elevation.

length.explanation: The 80-mile distance becomes substantially more challenging in the San Juan Mountains context. Routes like the Alpine Loop cover 65-80 miles but can take 6+ hours due to sustained grades above 10% and significant hike-a-bike sections on passes like Engineer and Cinnamon. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

technicality.explanation: San Juan Mountain routes feature grades exceeding 20% on bare rock sections. Imogene Pass is described as 'barely a road, a trail' with 'brutally steep and completely made of bare rock in certain sections.' Even 34x42 gearing is often insufficient. Among the most technical in gravel, on par with Badlands.

elevation.explanation: Starting at 7,792 ft and climbing through passes above 12,000 ft creates extreme elevation profiles. Imogene Pass tops out at 13,114 ft while Engineer Pass reaches 12,800 ft. The Alpine Loop alone gains over 3,300 ft through high-altitude terrain. Among the hilliest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

climate.explanation: The San Juan Range experiences 72-81 thunderstorm days annually - Colorado's highest. Monsoon season brings afternoon storms that can shift from clear skies to hail within minutes. The golden rule: be below treeline by noon during storm season. Among the most weather-friendly events, easier than Badlands.

altitude.explanation: Power output drops 20-30% at these elevations, with sustainable watts falling to 70-80% of sea level capacity at 12,000+ ft passes. Even acclimatized riders experience significant performance degradation in the thin air above Ouray's 7,792 ft starting elevation. Among the highest-altitude events in gravel, on par with Badlands.

adventure.explanation: The San Juan Mountains offer bucket-list terrain through historic mining routes and 13,000+ ft peaks. Black Bear Pass is labeled 'most dangerous 4x4 road in Colorado' while routes traverse moon-like landscapes above treeline through some of America's most remote high-altitude gravel.

prestige.explanation: No organized 'Ouray Gravel Grinder' event exists despite the area's reputation. The closest major event is the Telluride Gravel Race 25 miles away, while the region attracts dedicated bikepacking communities through self-supported adventures rather than formal racing.

race_quality.explanation: Without an organized event, there's no race infrastructure to evaluate. Self-supported riding means no aid stations, course marking, or official support. Riders navigate independently through terrain that demands complete self-sufficiency in extreme conditions.

experience.explanation: RMWilson describes events in mountain terrain as offering 'beautiful scenery, breakfast included, inexpensive camping spots' as an 'all around great event.' The San Juan landscape creates lasting memories through postcard Colorado scenery and extreme high-altitude challenges.

community.explanation: The lack of an established standalone event limits community development. While the Silverton Project historically ran 'Ouray Week' from 2016-2018, it moved to Silverton for fresh routes, indicating limited sustained event community in Ouray proper.

field_depth.explanation: No organized competition means no competitive field to assess. While individual riders tackle the San Juan Mountain terrain through self-supported adventures, this represents exploratory riding rather than structured racing with measurable field depth. Thinner field than Back Forty Highlander.

value.explanation: Without entry fees (no organized event), the riding itself offers exceptional value. Outstanding terrain accessible to anyone who can get there and is prepared for the challenge. Hot springs recovery is a bonus.

expenses.explanation: Lodging runs $250-300/night at properties like Twin Peaks Lodge with natural hot springs. Montrose airport provides reasonable access at 35 miles, though the remote location requires extended stays for proper altitude acclimation, increasing total trip costs. More affordable than Crusher in the Tushar.

race.notes: No clearly documented recurring 'Ouray Gravel Grinder' event with fixed organization. Scoring reflects the self-supported gravel riding experience in the Ouray/San Juan region based on Alpine Loop, Black Bear Pass, and Imogene Pass routes. Course profile scores reflect the exceptional difficulty of the terrain; editorial scores reflect the lack of organized event infrastructure. For organized racing, consider nearby Telluride Gravel Race.

final_verdict.one_liner: The Ouray Gravel Grinder doesn't exist as an organized race, but the San Juan Mountains will humble your FTP and test your ability to push a bike up 13,000-foot passes.
final_verdict.should_you_race: You can't race what isn't there, but if you're drawn to self-supported suffering in Colorado's most brutal terrain, bring a mountain bike and your hiking legs. The Alpine Loop and Imogene Pass will have you walking more than riding above 12,000 feet, and afternoon thunderstorms don't negotiate with your Strava segment dreams. This is bikepacking country masquerading as a gravel destination.
final_verdict.alternatives: Hit the actual Telluride Gravel Race 25 miles away for organized pain with 10,000 feet of climbing, or SBT GRVL in Steamboat for high-altitude suffering with better logistics and real competition instead of just you versus gravity.

course_description.character: Ouray serves up 80 miles of high-altitude punishment across mining roads that were never meant for bicycles. You'll grind through San Juan valleys on County Road 23 before the real show begins‚Äî12,000-foot alpine passes where your 34x42 becomes a prayer. This isn't gravel racing, it's controlled mountaineering on two wheels.

suffering_zones.label: County Road Reality Check
suffering_zones.desc: Rolling ranch roads through Ridgway Valley give you false confidence before the climbing starts. Use this time to dial in nutrition because things get serious fast.

suffering_zones.label: Alpine Loop Entry
suffering_zones.desc: The road tilts skyward toward Engineer Pass and your easy spinning ends forever. Welcome to 4WD mining roads where 10% grades are considered gentle.

suffering_zones.label: Engineer Pass Summit
suffering_zones.desc: At 12,800 feet, your lungs find out what thin air actually means. The descent is loose rock and exposure that'll make you religious about tire pressure.

suffering_zones.label: Cinnamon Pass Finale
suffering_zones.desc: Just when your legs are cooked, another 12,600-foot pass appears. The babyhead rocks and moon dust surface will test whatever's left in your soul.

course_description.signature_challenge: Engineer and Cinnamon passes back-to-back above 12,000 feet, where even Tour de France climbers end up walking sections. The altitude turns your FTP into a cruel joke, and the loose rock surfaces make every pedal stroke a negotiation with gravity.

unsplash_photos.description: Close-up of fine grey sand texture
a red fire hydrant sitting on the side of a road
A pile of small, smooth, multi-colored pebbles.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: Ouray Gravel Grinder gravel race Ouray

Gravel bikes keep pushing the limits, but this Parlee build takes a different approach. With a monocoque carbon frame, custom Chris King wheels, and Shimano GRX Di2, this bike is built for adventure‚Äînot just speed. From unique color pops to innovative components, here‚Äôs why this setup is as fascinating to ride as it is to build.

videos.title: Colorado Springs Gravel Ride
videos.description: 18 miles and 2200 vertical feet. Red Rock Canyon Open Space, North Cheyenne Canon, and Stratton Open Space.

videos.curation_reason: First-person gravel ride specifically above Ouray, Colorado with detailed terrain commentary and scenic views.

videos.title: Parlee Ouray Build | The Frame Is A Work Of ART!
videos.description:
Today we have a very special build here at Crafted Cycles as Alex builds up our first Parlee frame. Parlee are a high-end American brand and the quality of there frames has to be seen up close to be fully appreciated!

Looking to get your dream bike that fits you perfectly from the moment you get it? Check out our website or get in touch via our social media to start the process of building your dream bike:

Website - https://craftedcycles.co.uk/
Instagram - https://www.instagram.com/crafted_cycles/

Book A Bike Fit - https://ukbikefit.com/

At Crafted Cycles, we believe there‚Äôs a better way to buy a bike. The traditional model‚Äîlimited sizing and fixed components from major brands‚Äîjust doesn‚Äôt cut it. That‚Äôs why we launched our custom build workshop. You choose every part, from frame to components, so your bike fits perfectly and performs exactly how you want it to from day one. No more wasting money on upgrades or compromising on fit‚Äîjust a bike that‚Äôs built for you.

#parleebikes #parleeouray #roadbike #cycling #custombuild
videos.transcript:
Today we've got a really special build.
We're building a Parley Aura. It's their
flagship endurance bike. Really excited
to get it going. We've got the
components here. Let's go and get the
frame.
Here we have the Parley A. It's a super
nice, super light endurance frame bike.
Uh it's got clearance for 38 millimeter

Um it's just super compliant while still

but I reckon you can get a little bit
bigger in there. Another main benefit of

attention to detail. You get with the
bike a load of different headset
adapters, so you can literally run any
cockpit you want. This is great for us
because we're always trying to find the
perfect setup for the customer. So
whether you want to run a standard bar
or stem, a semi- integrated system like
this, or going full arrow, full
internal, there's an option for that. If
you enjoyed the bike build content, be
sure to like and subscribe on YouTube.
Uh we've got plenty more builds coming
out. And if you are interested in a
custom build, whether it's a parley or
one of the different brands we offer,
then please feel free to get in contact
with

videos.title: CBS SeaOtter 2024, Parlee Ouray launch day.
videos.transcript:
I'm Joseph from Cascade bicycle Studio
we've come all the way down here to
beautiful Monteray California SE otter
classic 2024 from Seattle uh we're here
to take you to get an exclusive look
with our brand Partners on some new
products that hopefully you'll see in
the studio this
[Applause]
[Music]
summer so I'm here with Tom uh with
parlay introducing the new uray that was
released this morning uh Tom uh some of
the focus points that we wanted to see
here is one um you guys are using a full
monocog
frame why um and then two you know what
is this who is this for what kind of
Rider is looking for this bike sure well
you know first off uh why on the mono um
well you know one piece construction
really is the best way to build a bike
right there's there's no seams there's
no areas um of you know Bond lines or
joints and what that means you know it's
kind of a you know a technical
Masterpiece but the byproduct is that
we're really able to dial in the
performance and especially the comfort
from from the bike so we're able to get
exactly the ride characteristics we want
and the Cosmetics that we want um so you
know what our dealers have been asking
us for the last couple years is just a
great all rounder you know just an
allround road bike and it's something
that's you know historically been our
best selling bike you know if you think
of uh the zed5 or the Z5 or the altum
it's always been kind of our number one
and so this really is the successor to
those to those bikes um you know there's
been a lot of influence um you know
again from from Riders and from dealers
the last couple years that you know have
kind of shaped the character of this
bike and you know added some things to
it that weren't in you know bikes like
the Ala um so yeah we're we're really
excited it's a it's just an awesome you
know I think modern road bike for the
way our customers want to ride you know
sure and with that level of monocog
construction you guys are actually
blending uh different carbon layups for
sizes right to kind of maintain that
characteristic uh of the parlay uh ride
quality yeah so I I think the thing you
know if you really talk to people who've
owned M you know many of our bikes over
the years the defining characteristics
of of a parley is that it has great
performance but it has an incredible
level of comfort without resorting to
gimmicks you know like suspension seat
posts or you know linkages or anything
like that the bikes just have a really
dialed ride quality and that just comes
from the way we tune the the Plies of
carbon and the type of carbon you know
how much of it and where it's located
and the angles of all the fibers in
there um but kind of to that to that
point one of the cool things about this
construction and if you look you know
kind of in this area here especially in
this area you you'll you'll notice that
there's no seam or joint in here and
almost every carbon bike in the market
has a joint in this area and it makes it
and or sometimes you joints in this area
too makes it really hard to get the the
compliance and the comfort in the seat
post that you want and that's the most
critical feature in terms of comfort um
this bike because of this type of
construction we're able to get 20% more
compliance out of the seat post you know
without changing diameters that's what
the exactly the same diameter seat post
that we've used round seat post that we
used on on its predecessors um so that's
something that immediately you know your
first hour on this bike you're going to
notice you know that comfort you know
and we had we didn't have to give up any
stiffness at the bottom bracket or any
stiffness you know in the main triangle
in terms of responsiveness to get that
um so I think that's something that you
know our Riders you know our our our
clients are going to love yeah yeah I'll
throw in a couple other little ones that
are super interesting uh and we're kind
of happy to see it from you guys we've
got a t47 threaded bottom bracket and No
Nonsense round seat post with a clamp uh
and then a modular front end uh and this
is not proprietary these are parts that
uh almost any bike shop can Source uh
which is kind of a wonderful thing so if
you buy this bike and for some reason
you know you're on a trip or uh move far
away from a parlay dealer uh you know
this is this is something that's built
to last and will stay around one more
thing it's got the udh hanger on it
there you go you know set up for the
future set up for the future but also
you know we've all had this happen I've
had it happen pretty recently you know
your bike gets you know in the travel
case something happens to it TSA does
their magic um you can go anywhere in
the world and get one of those hangers
um so we're we're pretty happy with you
know the open standard nature of it and
that's something that came from talking
to dealers right I mean that's where you
know this bike doesn't happen in a
vacuum you know and that's why we love
talking to you and you know and your
staff about hey this is what we want in
in a bike and and that's another thing
in terms of comfort that I just want to
reiterate about this bike and and that's
the fit um and we spend a I personally
spend a lot of time talking to Fitters
like you all around the country and all
around the world saying like hey how can
we make this bike fit
better how can we make this bike more
accessible to more Riders and I think
one of the things you'll notice um you
know and we could talk stack and reach
for another day um you know the bike
fits real Riders um but you see a lot
more top tube slope on this bike you
also see a lower bottom bracket yeah and
stand over height was something that we
heard uh over and over again from
dealers was on a road bike Believe It or
Not people want more stand over height
so more that's feedback that we receive
a lot you know with with being custom we
find a lot of people that are shorter a
lot of people that are super tall um and
then just oddly dimensioned um which you
can't buy the off-the-shelf bike and
then with that lower bottom bracket too
as the tires uh get bigger and bigger
you can still maintain that road bike
feel yeah yeah and I think I think
that's the thing that you'll notice you
know yes it has capacity for for really
big rubber but it was really designed
Around Tires you know in that 32 to 35
mm space yeah um you know and just an
all you know
allrounder but I think you'll find if
you want to take this out you know on a
go fast RP ride and everybody's there on
their go fast bike this bike will be
perfect for that be perfect for taking
on you know you know Grand Fondo sport
te centuries um again just an all round
kind of classic road bike awesome well
thank you so much for your time Tom hey
thanks yeah and good luck yeah
appreciate it

quotes.text: I was kind of bummed because they don't have mountain bike trails around here. It's really a 4x4 town. A lot of 4x4 passes and roads. So, I was like, 'What the heck? I'm going to get out on my bike. I'm going to go find some obscure dirt road and ride it and climb it.'
I didn't realize it was this steep when I was climbing. It feels a lot steeper when you're going down than when you're climbing up.
